snippet: A safety watchdog says an accident trend went unnoticed by regulators before the recall of two models last month.
abstract: Review of federal crash data by the Friedman Research Corporation reveals that 303 people died after air bags failed to deploy in two models included in General Motors recall of 1.6 million vehicles; adds to mounting reports of problems that went unheeded before GM announced recall because of faulty ignition switches; company criticizes use of the database, calling report speculative.

byline.original: By DANIELLE IVORY and HILARY STOUT
byline.contributor: Bill Vlasic and Christopher Jensen contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: A safety watchdog says an accident trend went unnoticed by regulators before the recall of two models last month.

headline.main: 303 Deaths Seen in G.M. Cars With Failed Air Bags
headline.print_headline: 303 Deaths Seen in G.M. Cars With Failed Air Bags
